title-group.article-title: Biomechanical Characterization of an Osteoporotic Artificial Bone Model for the Distal Femur

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Trauma-, Hand- and Reconstructive Surgery Friedrich Schiller University Jena, Erlanger Allee 101 07747 Jena, Germany
2AO Research Institute Davos (ARI), AO Foundation Clavadelerstr. 8, 7270 Davos, Switzerland
3Institute of Anatomy I, Friedrich Schiller University Jena Teichgraben 7, 07743 Jena, Germany
4Department of Trauma- and Reconstructive Surgery, BG-Kliniken Bergmannstrost Halle, Merseburger Str. 165, 06112 Halle, Germany

abstract.p: The treatment of osteoporotic distal femur fractures is still an unsolved problem of trauma surgery. The poor bone stock often leads to secondary loss of reduction and implant failure. Therefore, the development of new implants and their biomechanical testing is essential. In a previous study, we developed and initially characterized an artificial osteoporotic bone model of the distal femur. This follow-up study was performed to characterize this model in a biomechanical comparison. We investigated two different artificial bones: five foam cortical shell (Sawbones) and 10 custom-made artificial femoral condyles. Additionally, eight human femora were used for comparison. For biomechanical testing, two intramedullary nails (distal femur nail (DFN) and supracondylar nail (SCN)) were cyclically axial loaded in an AO 33 C2 unstable distal femoral fracture model. In our testing, the artificial bone showed a decrease in the axial stiffness of 27% for the SCN and 28% for the DFN compared to the human results. Also the number of cycles for a deformation of 2.5 mm was reduced by 55% (SCN) and 62% (DFN). This decrease was homogenous and caused by the relative high bone mineral density of the human specimen used. The modes of failure showed no difference between the artificial and human bones. Our customized artificial bone provides suitable results. In relation to the human bones classified as mildly osteoporotic, we assume that the biomechanical properties match to serve as an osteoporotic bone. Yet, we suggest to check transferability of the results with human material.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The treatment of osteoporotic fractures is still a challenge to every trauma surgeon and hence ranks high among the unsolved problems of modern trauma surgery [1]. The poor bone stock quality often avoids a stable fixation of the implant to the osteoporotic bone and leads to an insufficient reduction of the fracture with secondary loss of reduction, malunion, and malformation [2]. These facts led to the development of new implants to increase stability of the osteoporotic bone implant construct. For instance, the locking of intramedullary nails with a spiral blade (distal femur nail, DFN; Synthes, Solothurn, Switzerland) or four distal screws (supracondylar nail, SCN; Stryker, Schönkirch, Germany) and the angular stable interlocking of plates (less invasive stabilization system, LISS; Synthes, Solothurn, Switzerland) and intramedullary nails (angular stable locking system, ASLS; Synthes, Solothurn, Switzerland) should be mentioned. All these implants have been biomechanically tested in detail before their clinical application [1,3–5]. The biomechanical investigation of implants using osteoporotic bone is a big challenge due to the fact that human material has a large interindividual variation [6,7], is available in limited numbers only, and is expensive. At the moment, there are no artificial bones commercially available representing osteoporotic mechanical properties. Commercially available artificial bones (3rd generation composite bone, Sawbones Europe AB, Malmö, Sweden) for biomechanical testing simulate healthy, strong bones of young patients [8,9], although it is well known that structural and also mechanical properties of human bone change with lifetime. Osteoporosis is a disease of the bone which results in reduced bone mass and disrupted microarchitecture; these changes lead to a higher risk of fragile fractures. Lindahl and Lindgren described, on the one hand, the structural changes within aging of bone; they found a decrease in the apparent density and the area of bone. On the other hand, they investigated the changes in the mechanical properties with aging and found a decrease in compression strength and elastic modulus [6,7].

The aim of this study was the evaluation of a customized osteoporotic artificial bone resembling the distal part of the femur for its capability to biomechanical testing. The basic mechanical properties of the artificial bone were investigated in a previous study [10]. In this follow-up study, we performed a biomechanical evaluation of the artificial bone implant constructs and compared these results with the human bone.

sec.title: Foam Cortical Shell
sec.p: In the beginning, we used five foam cortical shell femora (FCS, Sawbones Europe AB, Malmö, Sweden) for the biomechanical testing (axial cyclic loading). The FCS is an artificial bone with a cortical shell and a cancellous filling. We used the FCS with a 12-mm intramedullary canal. This bone is not specially designed for biomechanical testing.

sec.title: Osteoporotic Artificial Bone
sec.p: This artificial bone resembling the distal 6.5 cm of a human femur was self-developed and custom made. It was produced from two-component polyurethane foam (H 75, VossChemie GmbH, Uetersen, Germany). The mean density was 150 kg/m3 (SD 5). For biomechanical testing, we used five of these femoral condyles; the part proximal to the fracture gap was a 3rd generation composite bone (Sawbones Europe AB, Malmö, Sweden).

sec.title: Human Bones
sec.p: Eight pairs of fresh frozen human femora (mean age 74 years; range 62–85; four male, four female) were used for this study. All femora were provided by our anatomical institute. The bones were harvested immediately after the donor’s death and stored at −20°C until mechanical testing. To exclude pathologies, X-rays were taken in two planes and bone mineral density (BMD) was measured using dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA, Lunar Prodigy Advance, General Electric Company; GE Healthcare; Madison, USA) [11]. Prior to mechanical testing, all bones were thawed to room temperature within 24 h and residual soft tissues were neatly removed.

sec.title: Implants
sec.p:
For this study, we used the distal femoral nail (DFN, Synthes GmbH, Solothurn, Switzerland) with a screw and a spiral blade for distal locking (Figure 1). The second implant used was the Supracondylar Femoral Nail (SCN, Stryker GmbH & Co. KG, Duisburg, Germany). It was locked with two fully threaded screws in an oblique direction; one from anterolateral to posteromedial and the other from anteromedial to posterolateral. Additionally, two screws with nuts were inserted from lateral to medial (Figure 1). Both nails were distally blocked with an end cap. The proximal locking was performed in both implants with two screws in the anterior–posterior direction. All implants were made of titan alloy (Ti6Al4V). Figure 1.
Implants used for biomechanical testing: SCN (Stryker, left); DFN (Synthes, right).

sec.title: Fracture Model
sec.p:
In this study we used an AO 33 C2 fracture model. For this a 15 mm fracture gap was created 6.5 cm above the knee joint line and parallel to it (Figure 2). Additionally, we did an osteotomy through the fossa intercondylaris. All osteotomies were created with custom-made jigs to standardize the fracture model. Figure 2.
Fracture model of the used AO 33 C2 fracture.

sec.title: Test Setup
sec.p:
For biomechanical testing, an electrohydraulic test machine (INSTRON 8874, Instron European Headquarters, High Wycombe, Bucks, United Kingdom) was used. Time, displacement, load, and number of cycles were acquired and plotted with use of MAX software (version 9.2; Instron, Canton, Massachusetts). Proximally, the specimens were embedded over a length of 10 cm in polyurethane resin and connected to the machine with a cardan joint. Distal femoral condyles were mounted on an ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene tibial insert of a total knee replacement and connected to the machine table with a cardan joint (Figure 3). Force was induced over the femoral head so as to align the mechanical axis of the femur with the machine axis (eccentric loading) [12]. Figure 3.
Test setup for cyclic axial loading: (1) upper cardan joint, (2) proximal fixation, (3) anatomical axis, (4) mechanical axis, (5) specimen, (6) distal fixation with PE-inlet, and (7) lower cardan joint.

sec.title: Cyclic Axial Loading
sec.p: Cyclic axial loading was performed incrementally, starting with an axial load oscillating between 20 and 200 N, at a rate of 2 Hz, and raising the lower limit by 10 N and the upper limit by 100 N after each 500-cycle step. The test was performed until failure of the specimen.
Incremental axial loading was established as a testing methodology by Marti et al. [3] and since then has been used by several investigators [4,13,14].

The initial axial stiffness of the constructs was obtained from cycles 50 through 59 of the first cyclic loading step. For that purpose, the slope of the linear area of the load–displacement curve was calculated for each of these cycles by linear regression and then, we determined the mean and SD.
As a parameter of strength, the cycles to 2.5 mm deformation were recorded. The displacement was determined from machine displacement. Additionally, the mode of failure was captured.

sec.title: Data Acquisition and Evaluation
sec.p: Data (displacement, force, and time) have been recorded from the machine built in sensors with 300 measurements per cycle. Data analysis was conducted using Excel (Microsoft 2003®, Microsoft GmbH, Unterschleißheim, Germany). For statistical analysis SSPS Version 13.00 for Windows (SSPS Inc., Chicago, Illinois) was used.

The Shapiro–Wilk test showed no normal distribution of the results, and so the Mann–Whitney test was used to identify the significant differences between the groups. Significance was assumed as p < 0.05.

sec.title: FCS Model
sec.p:
The FCS model was tested with the SCN only. The axial stiffness of the construct was 89 N/mm (SD 4.8). Failure occurred after a mean of 1065 cycles (SD 101) in the region of the most proximal locking screw in all five specimens (Figure 4). In the distal part no loss of reduction could be seen. This being a nonclinical relevant mode of failure, structure analysis of the FCS condyles was performed, where we found an approximately 5-mm thick cortical shell of solid polyurethane foam. This is not a representative of osteoporotic distal femurs where you can find only a very thin cortical shell of less than 1 mm (Figure 5). As a result, we developed and produced an artificial bone model resembling the distal part of the femur. Figure 4.
Failure mode of the SCN in the FCS model. Figure 5.
Human dried, defatted distal femur (left) and FCS model (right) with a cortical layer of approximately 5 mm.

sec.title: Cyclic Axial Loading
sec.p:
Mean axial stiffness in the human bones was 382 N/mm (SD 3.2) for the SCN and 358 N/mm (SD 13.8) for the DFN (p = 0.001). In the artificial bone, the mean stiffness of the SCN was 280 N/mm (SD 4.9) and of the DFN of 257 N/mm (SD 4.1) (p = 0.001). Using the artificial bone we achieved an axial stiffness of 73% for the SCN and 72% for the DFN compared to the human bone (Figure 6). Figure 6.
Axial stiffness (N/mm) of the SCN and DFN in the human and the artificial bone.

The mean number of cycles to a displacement of 2.5 mm was recorded. With the human bone, the SCN reached a mean of 10,729 cycles (SD 527) and the DFN 6210 cycles (SD 598) (p = 0.008). With the artificial bone, a mean of 4800 cycles (SD 196) for the SCN and 2338 cycles (SD 185) for the DFN were necessary to reach a deformation of 2.5 mm (p = 0.001). The osteoporotic artificial bone with the SCN reached a mean of 45% and the DFN 38% of the cycles for a deformation of 2.5 mm compared to the human bone (Figure 7). Figure 7.
Cycles to a displacement of 2.5 mm for SCN and DFN in human and artificial bone.

sec.title: Mode of Failure
sec.p:
The modes of failure differ significantly between the two used implants. The SCN was characterized by failure in the region of the medial locking screws due to a cut-out of the screws resulting in a varus collapse. Whereas, the DFN failed by loss of reduction in the intercondylar fracture gap widening from the distal to proximal region; additionally, a disruption of the medial condyle in the frontal plane was seen (Figure 8). Figure 8.
Failure modes of the DFN (right) and the SCN (left); comparison of the artificial bone (upper line) and the human specimen (lower line).

sec.title: Bone Mineral Density of Human Bones
sec.p: The evaluation of the BMD was performed by the regions of interest within the proximal femur. The mean total BMD was 0.83 g/cm2 (standard error mean, SEM 0.03).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This study investigated a customized artificial bone resembling the distal part of the femur for biomechanical testing. Due to the increasing number of fractures associated with osteoporosis, implant development has to address these special structural changes and the needs of these patients. Therefore, biomechanical testing has to be done with reliable artificial materials to identify potential improvements. In this study, we adapted the mechanical properties to simulate a severe osteoporotic bone. The basic mechanical properties have been investigated in the previous study [10]. The artificial bone was biomechanically tested with two different implants and the results were compared to the human bone. Within this study, we showed that our artificial bone is characterized by a very small variation for the axial stiffness and the cycles to 2.5 mm deformation. In comparison to the human bones, the tested biomechanical parameters (stiffness and deformation) are smaller, whereas the magnitude of difference between the human and artificial bones is almost the same for all tested parameters. Since the used human bones are classified as mildly osteoporotic (t-score −2) our artificial bone was intended to match the distal femora with severe osteoporosis [7]. The bone mineral density determined with DEXA is the standard in the diagnosis of osteoporosis. We determined the BMD in a setting with soft tissue simulation to secure the comparability with a standard population (t-score) and to categorize our specimens. The BMD (determined not only with DEXA but also with qualitative computed tomography (qCT)) is known to be a significant factor for the mechanical properties of human bone. With a decrease in BMD, the mechanical stability also decreases [15–18].

More and more artificial bones are used for biomechanical testing [19–21], but the interpretation of the results and even more clinical applicability is difficult, so the acceptance among surgeons is less. This is also caused by the fact that there are no artificial bones commercially available that represent osteoporotic mechanical conditions. In accordance with this we could show that the foam cortical shell femur (FSC, Sawbones Europe AB, Malmö, Sweden) is not appropriate to simulate the mechanical properties of an osteoporotic bone. Especially for the investigation of knee joint fractures and fractures close to the knee joint this artificial bone is not suitable because a 5 mm thick cortical shell is inappropriate for the distal femur.

For the development and evaluation of an artificial femur for biomechanical testing (3rd generation composite femur; 3rd GCB, Sawbones Europe AB, Malmö, Sweden) Papini et al. did finite element analyses and a mechanical comparison of intact human and artificial bones. They found an axial stiffness of 0.757 kN/mm for the human bones and 1.29 kN/mm for the 3rd GCB. In this study, no fracture or implant model was tested [9]. They concluded that the 3rd GCB represents the mechanical behavior of healthy femurs. A study of Zlowodzki et al. [4] shows that structural and mechanical properties are linked and have significant influence on the mode of failure; they tested two different plates for the treatment of distal femur fractures in healthy bone (high BMD) and found plastic deformation of the plate to be the only mode of failure [22]. This is not representing the difficulties in actual trauma surgery, where osteoporotic fractures become a major problem. Another study using artificial bone was performed by Snow et al. [23]. They investigated the LCP and DCP using polyurethane bars as an artificial osteoporotic bone (Synbone, Malans, Switzerland). They found the LCP to be mechanically advantageous than the DCP in axial compression when simulating an unstable osteoporotic fracture, but no investigation with human osteoporotic cadaver bones was made to check the comparability of these results. In our study, we decided to use two different implants and an unstable fracture model to evaluate the mechanical properties of our artificial femur. Additionally, we controlled the results with human femurs.

In the literature, the DFN and SCN have been compared in only one publication of Höhle et al. [24]. They had used an AO 33 A3 fracture model. In their investigation, the SCN reached higher values for the axial stiffness, but this difference was not statistically significant [24]. The enhanced stiffness and stability of the SCN compared to the DFN in our study is attributed to the differences in distal locking. While the DFN has one screw and one spiral blade in one plane the SCN is distally locked in a three-plane configuration with two fully threaded screws in the oblique direction. These screws are, compared to lateromedial screws, longer and reach the denser cancellous bone of the posterior condyles [25]. Additionally, the condyle screws with washer and nuts can provide compression in the fracture gap.

In summary, we can say that our artificial bone resembling the distal part of the femur can be used to perform biomechanical investigations of severe osteoporotic conditions/fractures and to perform implant testing. In our testing, the artificial bone showed a decrease in the axial stiffness of 27% for the SCN and 28% for the DFN compared to human bone. Also, the number of cycles for the deformation of 2.5 mm was reduced by 55% (SCN) and 62% (DFN). This decrease was homogenous and caused by the relatively high bone mineral density of the human specimen. The modes of failure showed no difference between the artificial and human bones. The failure modes in the incremental cyclic axial test observed by us have been reported by other authors, both in synthetic bone models and in human femora [26–29]. These authors describe different types of cutout for the DFN and other intramedullary nails with additional displacement of the medial fracture compartment and closure of the fracture gap; the same mode as that of the SCN and DFN. Based on our test setup we found, in addition to the cutout for the DFN, a widening of the C-component and a split of the medial condyle in the frontal plane.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Our customized artificial bone model of the distal femur is assumed to feature the biomechanical characteristics of severe osteoporotic bone. However, since we had only a mildly osteoporotic bone as reference, we stuck for an ultimate proof of this thesis. Yet, we suggest to check biomechanical studies using artificial bone by performing a part of the tests with human material to control the transferability of the results.

sec.title: CLINICAL RELEVANCE
sec.p: This study is of high indirect clinical relevance since osteoporotic fractures are a demanding issue in orthopaedic surgery requiring implants with improved anchoring in the poor bone stock. In the development of such ‘improved’ implants, extensive biomechanical testing is essential presuming reliable artificial bone models.
